docs.title: Welcome to Flowlence Learn
docs.text: Welcome to the official tutorials and learning resources for Flowlence Code - a block-based programming environment for IoT and Robotics using the ESP32 microcontroller.

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
• Getting Started

    Download, install, and write your first program in minutes.

    Get started

  • Sensors & Modules

    Learn how each sensor works, how to wire it, and how to program it.

    Explore sensors

  • Projects

    Build complete projects that combine multiple sensors and concepts.

    View projects

docs.title: What You'll Need
docs.text:
• Flowlence Code software (free download)
  • ESP32 microcontroller (included in your kit)
  • Sensors and modules (included in your kit)
  • USB cable to connect ESP32 to your computer
  • Jumper wires and a breadboard

docs.title: How To Use This Tutorial
docs.text:
1. Start with Getting Started to install the software and run your first program
  2. Work through the Sensors & Modules section to understand each component
  3. Combine what you've learned in the Projects section

Each sensor tutorial follows the same structure:

  • What is it? - What the sensor does and how it works
  • Wiring Diagram - How to connect it to the ESP32
  • Code - Block-based program with step-by-step explanation
  • Try It - A challenge to test your understanding

docs.title: Your First Program
docs.text: In this tutorial, you'll make the built-in LED on your ESP32 blink on and off. No extra components needed - just your ESP32 and a USB cable.

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
• How to connect your ESP32 to Flowlence Code
  • How to use basic blocks (Events, Pins, Control)
  • How to upload a program to your ESP32

docs.title: Step 1: Connect Your ESP32
docs.text:
1. Plug your ESP32 into your computer using the USB cable
  2. In Flowlence Code, click ESP32 in the menu bar
  3. Click Connect and select the COM port that appears

Tip

If no COM port appears, you may need to install the USB driver. See Troubleshooting.

docs.title: Step 2: Build the Program
docs.text:
Drag the following blocks into your workspace:

Here's what each block does:

  1. when Arduino begin - This is where your program starts
  2. forever - Repeats everything inside it endlessly
  3. set pin 2 to HIGH - Turns the LED on (pin 2 is the built-in LED)
  4. wait 1 seconds - Pauses for 1 second
  5. set pin 2 to LOW - Turns the LED off
  6. wait 1 seconds - Pauses for 1 second again

docs.title: Step 3: Upload
docs.text:
1. Click the Upload button (green arrow)
  2. Wait for the code to compile and upload
  3. Watch your ESP32 - the LED should start blinking!

Congratulations!

You've just written and uploaded your first program. The LED on your ESP32 should be blinking on and off every second.

docs.title: Understanding the Code
docs.text:
Look at the Code Panel on the right side. You'll see the Arduino code that was generated from your blocks:

void setup() {
    pinMode(2, OUTPUT);
}

void loop() {
    digitalWrite(2, HIGH);
    delay(1000);
    digitalWrite(2, LOW);
    delay(1000);
}

This is the same program written in text-based code. As you learn more blocks, you'll start to understand the code behind them.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Can you make the LED blink faster? Try changing the wait time from 1 second to 0.5 seconds.

Bonus: Can you make the LED stay on for 2 seconds and off for 0.5 seconds?

docs.title: Next Step
docs.text: Now that you can upload programs, let's learn about the sensors and modules in your kit!

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
• Operating System: Windows 10 or later
  • RAM: 4 GB minimum
  • Disk Space: 2 GB free space
  • USB Port: Required for connecting the ESP32

docs.title: Download
docs.text:
Download the latest version of Flowlence Code from the official website:

Download Flowlence Code

docs.title: Step 1: Run the Installer
docs.text: Double-click the downloaded .exe file to start the installation.

docs.title: Step 2: Choose Installation Location
docs.text: The default location is C:\Program Files\Flowlence Code. Click Install to proceed.

docs.title: Step 3: Wait for Installation
docs.text: The installer will download required components. This may take a few minutes depending on your internet connection.

docs.title: Step 4: Launch Flowlence Code
docs.text:
Once installation is complete, click Finish to launch Flowlence Code.

You're ready!

If you see the Flowlence Code interface, the installation was successful. Continue to the Interface Tour to learn your way around.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Installation stuck at 17%?

This usually means the external resources are still downloading. Make sure you have a stable internet connection and wait for the download to complete.

Windows SmartScreen warning?

If Windows shows a SmartScreen warning, click More info and then Run anyway. This happens because the app is new and hasn't yet built up a reputation with Microsoft.

docs.title: Interface Tour
docs.text: This guide will walk you through the main areas of the Flowlence Code interface.

docs.title: 1. Menu Bar
docs.text:
The top bar contains:

  • File - Save, load, and create new projects
  • Edit - Undo, redo operations
  • Device Selector - Choose your ESP32 board
  • Connection Status - Shows if your board is connected
  • Project Name - Click to rename your project
  • Upload Firmware - Flash firmware to your ESP32
  • Program Mode - Toggle between upload and real-time mode

docs.title: 2. Block Categories (Left Panel)
docs.text:
Blocks are organized into categories:

Category Description Events Starting blocks like "when Arduino begin" Control Loops, conditions, waits Operators Math and logic operations Variables Create and use variables My Blocks Custom blocks you create Pins Digital and analog pin control Serial Serial monitor communication Data Data types and conversions

docs.title: 3. Workspace (Center)
docs.text:
This is where you drag and connect blocks to build your program.

  • Drag blocks from the left panel into the workspace
  • Connect blocks by snapping them together
  • Right-click a block for options (duplicate, delete, help)
  • Scroll to zoom in/out

docs.title: 4. Code Panel (Right)
docs.text: Shows the Arduino C++ code generated from your blocks in real-time. This helps you learn text-based coding as you build with blocks.

docs.title: 5. Serial Monitor (Bottom Right)
docs.text: Displays messages sent from your ESP32 using Serial Print blocks. Useful for debugging and reading sensor values.

docs.title: Next Step
docs.text: Now that you know the interface, let's write your first program!

docs.title: Projects
docs.text: Projects combine multiple sensors and concepts from the individual tutorials into complete, functional systems. Make sure you've gone through the relevant sensor tutorials before starting a project.

docs.title: Available Projects
docs.text: Project Sensors Used Difficulty Smart Lighting System LED, LDR, Button Beginner Alarm System PIR, Buzzer, LED Beginner Weather Station DHT11, LCD, LED Intermediate Auto Plant Watering Soil Moisture, Relay, LCD Intermediate IoT Dashboard DHT11, WiFi, ThingsBoard Advanced

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
Each project includes:

  1. Overview - What you'll build and why it's useful
  2. Components Needed - List of sensors and modules
  3. Wiring Diagram - Complete circuit with all components
  4. Step-by-Step Code - Build the program block by block
  5. Testing - How to verify everything works
  6. Extend It - Ideas to make the project your own

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Build a motion-activated alarm system using a PIR sensor, buzzer, and LED. When motion is detected, the alarm sounds and the LED flashes. This is the basis of real home security systems.

docs.title: Components Needed
docs.text:
• ESP32
  • PIR Motion Sensor
  • Buzzer
  • LED
  • 220 ohm resistor
  • Jumper wires

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text: Component ESP32 Pin PIR Signal GPIO 27 Buzzer + GPIO 5 LED (through resistor) GPIO 2

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
┌──────────────────┐
│  Read PIR sensor  │
└────────┬──────────┘
         │
    ┌────▼─────┐
    │ Motion   │──── Yes ──── Sound buzzer + Flash LED
    │ detected?│              for 5 seconds
    └────┬─────┘
         │ No
         │
    Everything OFF, keep watching

docs.title: Step-by-Step Code
docs.text: Coming soon - screenshots of Flowlence Code blocks will be added here.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
1. Upload the code and wait 30-60 seconds for the PIR to stabilize
  2. Walk in front of the PIR sensor
  3. The buzzer should sound and the LED should flash
  4. After 5 seconds of no motion, the alarm should stop

docs.title: Extend It
docs.text:
• Add a button to arm/disarm the alarm
  • Display "ALERT!" on an LCD when motion is detected
  • Add a count of how many times motion was detected

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Build an automated plant watering system that monitors soil moisture and activates a water pump when the soil is too dry. The LCD displays the current moisture level and system status.

docs.title: Components Needed
docs.text:
• ESP32
  • Soil Moisture Sensor
  • Relay Module
  • Small Water Pump
  • LCD Display (I2C)
  • Jumper wires

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text: Component ESP32 Pin Soil Moisture Signal GPIO 35 Relay IN GPIO 26 LCD SDA GPIO 21 LCD SCL GPIO 22

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
┌─────────────────────┐
│ Read soil moisture    │
└────────┬─────────────┘
         │
┌────────▼─────────────┐
│ Display moisture      │
│ level on LCD          │
└────────┬─────────────┘
         │
    ┌────▼──────┐
    │ Soil dry? │──── Yes ──── Turn ON pump (relay)
    └────┬──────┘              Wait 3 seconds
         │ No                  Turn OFF pump
         │
    Pump stays OFF
    Wait 10 seconds, repeat

docs.title: Step-by-Step Code
docs.text: Coming soon - screenshots of Flowlence Code blocks will be added here.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
1. Upload the code to your ESP32
  2. Insert the soil moisture sensor into dry soil
  3. The LCD should show a high value and the pump should activate
  4. Add water to the soil - the value drops and the pump stops

docs.title: Extend It
docs.text:
• Add an LED indicator (green = moist, red = dry)
  • Set different moisture thresholds for different plants
  • Send moisture data to an IoT dashboard

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Connect your ESP32 to the internet and send sensor data to a cloud dashboard using MQTT. You'll see real-time graphs and widgets showing your sensor readings from anywhere in the world.

This project uses Flowlence Cloud (powered by ThingsBoard) for the dashboard.

docs.title: Components Needed
docs.text:
• ESP32
  • DHT11 Temperature & Humidity Sensor
  • WiFi connection
  • Flowlence Cloud account

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting this project, make sure you've completed:

  • DHT11 Tutorial - understand the sensor
  • Your First Program - know how to upload code

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
┌──────────┐    WiFi/MQTT    ┌─────────────────┐
│  ESP32   │ ──────────────► │ Flowlence Cloud  │
│  + DHT11 │                 │  (Dashboard)     │
└──────────┘                 └─────────────────┘
  Reads temp                   Shows graphs,
  & humidity                   gauges, alerts
  every 5 sec                  in real-time

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: A live dashboard showing temperature and humidity graphs updating in real-time as your ESP32 sends data.

docs.title: Extend It

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Build an automatic lighting system that turns on when it gets dark and can also be manually controlled with a button. This is how real streetlights and smart home lights work.

docs.title: Components Needed
docs.text:
• ESP32
  • LED
  • LDR (Light sensor)
  • Push button
  • 220 ohm resistor
  • Jumper wires

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text: Component ESP32 Pin LED (through resistor) GPIO 2 LDR Signal GPIO 34 Button GPIO 4

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
┌─────────────────┐
│  Read light      │
│  sensor (LDR)    │
└────────┬─────────┘
         │
    ┌────▼────┐
    │ Is it   │──── Yes ──── Turn LED ON
    │ dark?   │
    └────┬────┘
         │ No
    ┌────▼─────┐
    │ Button   │──── Yes ──── Toggle LED
    │ pressed? │
    └────┬─────┘
         │ No
         │
    LED stays OFF

docs.title: Step 1: Setup
docs.text: Set up pin modes for the LED (output), LDR (analog input), and button (input with pull-up).

docs.title: Step 2: Read the Light Level
docs.text: Read the analog value from the LDR. If the value is below 1000 (dark), turn the LED on automatically.

docs.title: Step 3: Add Button Control
docs.text: Add a button check so the user can manually override the automatic lighting.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
1. Upload the code to your ESP32
  2. Cover the LDR with your hand - the LED should turn on
  3. Uncover the LDR - the LED should turn off
  4. Press the button - the LED should toggle regardless of light level

docs.title: Extend It
docs.text:
• Add a second LED for brighter lighting
  • Use PWM to adjust LED brightness based on how dark it is
  • Add a buzzer that beeps when switching modes

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Build a weather station that reads temperature and humidity and displays the data on an LCD screen. An LED indicator warns when temperature exceeds a threshold.

docs.title: Components Needed
docs.text:
• ESP32
  • DHT11 Temperature & Humidity Sensor
  • LCD Display (I2C)
  • LED
  • 220 ohm resistor
  • Jumper wires

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text: Component ESP32 Pin DHT11 Data GPIO 15 LCD SDA GPIO 21 LCD SCL GPIO 22 LED (through resistor) GPIO 2

docs.title: Step-by-Step Code
docs.text: Coming soon - screenshots of Flowlence Code blocks will be added here.

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
1. Upload the code to your ESP32
  2. The LCD should display current temperature and humidity
  3. Breathe on the DHT11 sensor to see humidity increase
  4. Values update every 2 seconds

docs.title: Extend It
docs.text:
• Add a buzzer alarm for extreme temperatures
  • Log data to the Serial Monitor for analysis
  • Send data to an IoT dashboard (see IoT Dashboard project)

docs.title: Sensors & Modules
docs.text: This section covers every sensor and module included in your Flowlence IoT Kit. Each tutorial is self-contained - you can follow them in any order.

docs.title: What's in Your Kit
docs.text: Module Description Difficulty LED Light Emitting Diode - basic output Beginner Button Push button - basic input Beginner Buzzer Sound output - tones and alarms Beginner Servo Motor Precise angle control motor Beginner Ultrasonic Sensor Distance measurement Intermediate DHT11 Temperature & humidity sensor Intermediate Light Sensor (LDR) Light level detection Beginner PIR Motion Sensor Motion detection Intermediate Soil Moisture Sensor Soil water content Intermediate Water Level Sensor Water depth detection Intermediate LCD Display 16x2 character display Intermediate Relay Module Control high-power devices Advanced

docs.title: Tutorial Structure
docs.text:
Each sensor tutorial follows the same format:

  1. What is it? - What the sensor does and how it works
  2. Specifications - Pin layout and technical details
  3. Wiring Diagram - How to connect it to the ESP32
  4. Code - Block-based program with explanation
  5. Expected Result - What you should see when it works
  6. Try It! - A challenge to test your understanding

docs.title: Wiring Color Convention
docs.text:
Throughout these tutorials, we use the following wire colors:

Wire Color Purpose Red Power (VCC / 3.3V / 5V) Black Ground (GND) Yellow Signal / Data Blue Additional signal (when needed)

Important

Always double-check your wiring before powering on. Incorrect wiring can damage your sensors or ESP32.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A push button is a simple input device. When you press it, it closes a circuit and sends a signal to the ESP32. Buttons are used to trigger actions - like turning an LED on/off, starting a motor, or sending data.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
A button has 4 pins, but only 2 pairs matter. When pressed, it connects the circuit. We use a pull-up resistor configuration, meaning the pin reads HIGH normally and LOW when pressed.

Tip

The ESP32 has built-in pull-up resistors, so you don't need an external one. We enable it in the code using INPUT_PULLUP.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Type Momentary push button Pin Type Digital Input States Pressed (LOW) / Released (HIGH)

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Button Pin ESP32 Pin One leg GPIO 4 Other leg GND

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text:
1. Connect one leg of the button to GPIO 4
  2. Connect the other leg to GND

docs.title: Read Button State
docs.text:
How it works:

Block What It Does when Arduino begin Program starts here set pin 4 mode INPUT_PULLUP Configures pin 4 as input with pull-up resistor forever Repeats the blocks inside if read digital pin 4 = LOW Checks if button is pressed set pin 2 to HIGH Turns LED on when button is pressed else When button is not pressed set pin 2 to LOW Turns LED off

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: When you press the button, the LED turns on. When you release it, the LED turns off.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Modify the program so that pressing the button toggles the LED: press once to turn on, press again to turn off.

Hint: You'll need a variable to remember the LED's current state.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A buzzer is a small device that produces sound. There are two types: active buzzers (make a fixed tone when powered) and passive buzzers (can play different tones and melodies). Your kit includes a passive buzzer, which gives you more control.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: A passive buzzer vibrates at the frequency of the signal it receives. By changing the frequency, you can produce different musical notes. Higher frequency = higher pitch.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Type Passive buzzer Operating Voltage 3.3V - 5V Pin Type Digital/PWM Output Frequency Range 20Hz - 20kHz

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Buzzer Pin ESP32 Pin + (Signal) GPIO 5 - (Ground) GND

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text:
1. Connect the + pin of the buzzer to GPIO 5
  2. Connect the - pin to GND

docs.title: Play a Tone
docs.text:
How it works:

Block What It Does set buzzer pin 5 tone 262 Plays middle C (262 Hz) wait 0.5 seconds Hold the note for half a second set buzzer pin 5 off Stops the sound

docs.title: Play a Simple Melody
docs.text:
You can play different notes in sequence to create a melody. Common frequencies:

Note Frequency (Hz) C 262 D 294 E 330 F 349 G 392 A 440 B 494

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: You should hear tones playing from the buzzer. If playing a melody, you'll hear a sequence of different notes.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Program the buzzer to play a simple melody of your choice. Try "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" (C C G G A A G).

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: The DHT11 sensor measures both temperature and humidity in the air. It's commonly used in weather stations, smart homes, and greenhouses.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: The DHT11 contains a humidity-sensing component and a temperature-sensing component. It sends data digitally through a single data pin, providing both readings in one connection.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Temperature Range 0 - 50 °C (±2°C accuracy) Humidity Range 20 - 80% RH (±5% accuracy) Operating Voltage 3.3V - 5V Pins VCC, Data, GND

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Sensor Pin ESP32 Pin VCC 3.3V Data GPIO 15 GND GND

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
How it works:

Block What It Does read DHT11 pin 15 temperature Reads temperature in Celsius read DHT11 pin 15 humidity Reads humidity percentage serial print Displays values in the Serial Monitor

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: The Serial Monitor shows temperature and humidity readings, updating every 2 seconds. Try breathing on the sensor to see the humidity spike.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Create a temperature alert: if the temperature goes above 30°C, turn on an LED and buzzer.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A 16x2 LCD display shows text on a screen with 2 rows of 16 characters each. The I2C version uses only 2 data wires (instead of 6+), making wiring much simpler.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Display 16 columns x 2 rows Interface I2C (address 0x27) Operating Voltage 5V Pins VCC, GND, SDA, SCL

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: LCD Pin ESP32 Pin VCC 5V GND GND SDA GPIO 21 SCL GPIO 22

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: The LCD displays your text on the screen. You can show sensor readings, messages, or any text up to 16 characters per line.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Display the temperature and humidity from a DHT11 sensor on the LCD. Show temperature on line 1 and humidity on line 2.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: An LDR (Light Dependent Resistor), also called a photoresistor, detects light levels. Its resistance decreases when light shines on it and increases in darkness. It's used in automatic streetlights, daylight sensors, and light-following robots.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Type Analog sensor Output Range 0 - 4095 (ESP32 ADC) Operating Voltage 3.3V

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Sensor Pin ESP32 Pin Signal GPIO 34 VCC 3.3V GND GND

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
How it works:

Block What It Does read analog pin 34 Reads light level (0 = dark, 4095 = bright) serial print Displays the value in Serial Monitor

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: The Serial Monitor shows a number between 0 and 4095. Cover the sensor to see the value drop. Shine a light on it to see the value increase.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Build an automatic night light: when the light level drops below a threshold, turn on an LED automatically.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: An LED (Light Emitting Diode) is a small light that turns on when electricity flows through it. LEDs are found everywhere - in traffic lights, phone screens, and decorations. In this tutorial, you'll learn how to control an LED with your ESP32.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
An LED has two legs:

  • Long leg (Anode / +) - connects to the signal pin
  • Short leg (Cathode / -) - connects to ground (GND)

When the ESP32 sends a HIGH signal to the pin, current flows through the LED and it lights up. When it sends LOW, the LED turns off.

Why do we need a resistor?

A resistor (220 ohm) is placed in series with the LED to limit the current. Without it, too much current flows and the LED can burn out.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Operating Voltage 2V - 3.3V Recommended Resistor 220 ohm Pin Type Digital Output

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: LED Pin ESP32 Pin Anode (+) through 220 ohm resistor GPIO 2 Cathode (-) GND

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text:
1. Connect the long leg of the LED to a 220 ohm resistor
  2. Connect the other end of the resistor to GPIO 2 on the ESP32
  3. Connect the short leg of the LED to GND on the ESP32

docs.title: Basic: Turn LED On and Off
docs.text:
Drag these blocks into your workspace:

How it works:

Block What It Does when Arduino begin Program starts here forever Repeats the blocks inside set pin 2 to HIGH Sends power to GPIO 2, turning the LED on wait 1 seconds Pauses for 1 second set pin 2 to LOW Stops power to GPIO 2, turning the LED off wait 1 seconds Pauses for 1 second

docs.title: Advanced: LED Brightness Control (PWM)
docs.text:
You can also control the brightness of the LED using PWM (Pulse Width Modulation). Instead of just ON or OFF, PWM rapidly switches the pin on and off to simulate different brightness levels.

How it works:

Block What It Does set pwm pin 2 to 0 LED fully off set pwm pin 2 to 128 LED half brightness set pwm pin 2 to 255 LED fully on

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text:
• Basic: The LED blinks on for 1 second, then off for 1 second, repeating forever.
  • Advanced: The LED gradually gets brighter, then dimmer, creating a "breathing" effect.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge 1

Make the LED blink 3 times quickly, then pause for 2 seconds, then repeat.

Challenge 2

Create a "breathing" effect where the LED slowly fades in and out using PWM.

Hint: Use a variable that increases from 0 to 255, then decreases back to 0.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A PIR (Passive Infrared) sensor detects motion by sensing changes in infrared radiation. When a person or animal moves in front of the sensor, it outputs a HIGH signal. It's used in security systems, automatic lights, and occupancy detection.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Detection Range Up to 7 meters Detection Angle ~120 degrees Output Digital (HIGH when motion detected) Operating Voltage 3.3V - 5V

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Sensor Pin ESP32 Pin VCC 5V Signal GPIO 27 GND GND

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text:
Info

After powering on, the PIR sensor needs about 30-60 seconds to stabilize. Motion detection during this time may be unreliable.

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: When you walk in front of the sensor, the Serial Monitor prints "Motion detected!" and the LED turns on. After a few seconds of no motion, the LED turns off.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Build a simple security alarm: when motion is detected, sound a buzzer for 3 seconds and blink an LED.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A relay is an electrically controlled switch. It allows the ESP32 (which operates at 3.3V) to control high-power devices like water pumps, fans, and lights that require more voltage. Think of it as a bridge between your low-power ESP32 and high-power devices.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: When the ESP32 sends a HIGH signal to the relay, an internal electromagnet activates and closes a switch. This connects the high-power circuit, turning on the connected device.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Control Voltage 3.3V - 5V Switching Capacity Up to 10A at 250V AC Trigger HIGH = ON (active high) Pins VCC, GND, Signal

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Relay Pin ESP32 Pin VCC 5V GND GND IN (Signal) GPIO 26

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text:
Safety Warning

Relays can switch high-voltage circuits. In these tutorials, we only use the relay with low-voltage devices (small water pumps, fans). Never connect mains electricity (wall outlet) without proper supervision and safety measures.

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: The relay clicks on and off. If a water pump is connected, it turns on for 3 seconds then off for 3 seconds.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Combine the relay with the soil moisture sensor: when soil is dry, activate the relay to turn on a water pump. When soil is moist, turn it off.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A servo motor is a motor that can rotate to a specific angle (0 to 180 degrees). Unlike regular motors that just spin, servos let you control the exact position. They're used in robotic arms, doors, gates, and steering mechanisms.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text: A servo has 3 wires: power (red), ground (brown/black), and signal (orange/yellow). The ESP32 sends a PWM signal to tell the servo what angle to move to.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Rotation Range 0 - 180 degrees Operating Voltage 4.8V - 6V Signal Type PWM Wires Red (VCC), Brown (GND), Orange (Signal)

docs.title: Wiring Diagram
docs.text:
Warning

Servos draw more current than most sensors. If using multiple servos, consider an external power supply.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
How it works:

Block What It Does set servo pin 13 angle 0 Moves servo to 0 degrees wait 1 seconds Waits 1 second set servo pin 13 angle 90 Moves servo to 90 degrees (middle) wait 1 seconds Waits 1 second set servo pin 13 angle 180 Moves servo to 180 degrees (full rotation)

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: The servo should rotate to 0, then 90, then 180 degrees with 1-second pauses between each position.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Create a program that slowly sweeps the servo from 0 to 180 degrees and back, like a radar. Use a variable that increases by 1 each loop.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A soil moisture sensor measures the water content in soil. It outputs an analog value that corresponds to the moisture level. It's used in automated irrigation systems, smart gardens, and agriculture.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Type Analog sensor Output Range 0 - 4095 (ESP32 ADC) Operating Voltage 3.3V - 5V

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Sensor Pin ESP32 Pin Signal GPIO 35 VCC 3.3V GND GND

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: Insert the sensor into soil. Dry soil gives a high value, wet soil gives a low value. The Serial Monitor shows the readings in real-time.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Create a plant monitoring system: display "Dry - Water needed!" on the Serial Monitor when soil moisture drops below a threshold, and "Moist - All good!" when it's adequate.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: An ultrasonic sensor measures distance by sending out a sound wave and timing how long it takes to bounce back. It works like a bat's echolocation. The HC-SR04 can measure distances from 2 cm to 400 cm.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. The sensor sends a burst of ultrasonic sound (40 kHz, inaudible to humans)
  2. The sound bounces off an object and returns
  3. The sensor measures the time it took for the echo to return
  4. Distance is calculated from the time

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Measuring Range 2 cm - 400 cm Accuracy ~3 mm Operating Voltage 5V Pins VCC, Trig, Echo, GND

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Sensor Pin ESP32 Pin VCC 5V Trig GPIO 12 Echo GPIO 14 GND GND

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
How it works:

Block What It Does read ultrasonic trig 12 echo 14 Reads distance in centimeters serial print Displays the distance in the Serial Monitor

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: Open the Serial Monitor to see distance readings updating in real-time. Move your hand closer to or farther from the sensor to see the values change.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Create a parking sensor: when an object is closer than 20 cm, turn on a buzzer. The closer the object, the faster the buzzer beeps.

docs.title: What Is It?
docs.text: A water level sensor detects the depth of water by measuring conductivity between exposed traces on the board. The more traces are submerged, the higher the reading. It's used in flood detection, water tanks, and aquariums.

docs.title: Specifications
docs.text: Property Value Type Analog sensor Output Range 0 - 4095 (ESP32 ADC) Operating Voltage 3.3V - 5V Detection Depth Up to 4 cm

docs.title: Pin Layout
docs.text: Sensor Pin ESP32 Pin Signal GPIO 36 VCC 3.3V GND GND

docs.title: Expected Result
docs.text: Dip the sensor into water gradually. The Serial Monitor shows increasing values as more of the sensor is submerged.

docs.title: Try It!
docs.text:
Challenge

Create a water level alarm: when the water level exceeds a threshold, sound a buzzer to warn of flooding.
